flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction_rendered:
Relevant parts
  • Freezer Box
  • Blackout Fabric or Blackout Foil
  • Lab Tape
  • 1 Lonza FlashGel Cassette
Tools
  • Razor

parts.notes: Some of them have holes the bottom, preferably ones without holes. Regardless, it's easy to cover the holes up.

lines.text: Separate the freezer box covers and bases. The bases will be used as the sides of the camera box, and will act as barriers to prevent light from entering. One of the covers will be placed over the flash gel, the other will be to support the iPhone camera.
lines.text_raw: Separate the freezer box covers and bases. The bases will be used as the sides of the camera box, and will act as barriers to prevent light from entering. One of the covers will be placed over the flash gel, the other will be to support the iPhone camera.

lines.text: In the Solidworks images used in this tutorial, the bases are blue, while the covers are grey.
lines.text_raw: In the Solidworks images used in this tutorial, the bases are blue, while the covers are grey.

lines.text: Take one of the cover pieces and cut out one of the side flaps. Then cut out a hole through the top face the size of the gel portion on the cassette.
lines.text_raw: Take one of the cover pieces and cut out one of the side flaps. Then cut out a hole through the top face the size of the gel portion on the cassette.

lines.text: Take both of the base pieces (blue), and cut out an edge flap, just like you did with the cover piece.
lines.text_raw: Take both of the base pieces (blue), and cut out an edge flap, just like you did with the cover piece.

lines.text: Take the razor and cut out a rectangle as shown from the FlashGel Cassette. This piece will be a filter for the camera, to filter the blue light from the FlashGel.
lines.text_raw: Take the razor and cut out a rectangle as shown from the FlashGel Cassette. This piece will be a filter for the camera, to filter the blue light from the FlashGel.

lines.text: Make sure to wear gloves and take precautionary measures to prevent the contents of the cassette from spilling or getting on your skin.
lines.text_raw: Make sure to wear gloves and take precautionary measures to prevent the contents of the cassette from spilling or getting on your skin.

lines.text: . Attach the base piece to the sides so that the cut out side is facing towards the bottom. Do this for both base pieces.
lines.text_raw: . Attach the base piece to the sides so that the cut out side is facing towards the bottom. Do this for both base pieces.

lines.text: Take the last uncut cover piece, and attach it to the inside top of box.
lines.text_raw: Take the last uncut cover piece, and attach it to the inside top of box.

lines.text: Use tape or glue to secure the freezer boxes together.
lines.text_raw: Use tape or glue to secure the freezer boxes together.

lines.text: Then, using a sharp tipped pen, or screwdriver create a hole for the camera in the center of the top cover. For an iPhone camera, the hole should be about 1/2 an inch in diameter.
lines.text_raw: Then, using a sharp tipped pen, or screwdriver create a hole for the camera in the center of the top cover. For an iPhone camera, the hole should be about 1/2 an inch in diameter.

lines.text: Underneath the camera hole, tape the orange filter that you cut out earlier.
lines.text_raw: Underneath the camera hole, tape the orange filter that you cut out earlier.

lines.text: Tape the blackout material all around the outside and inside of the box.
lines.text_raw: Tape the blackout material all around the outside and inside of the box.

lines.text: *Tip: It might be easier to tape the blackout fabric onto the pieces as you attach them together.
lines.text_raw: *Tip: It might be easier to tape the blackout fabric onto the pieces as you attach them together.

lines.text: A comparison of pictures taken from the FlashGel camera and from an iPhone (3GS) camera using our DIY box.
lines.text_raw: A comparison of pictures taken from the FlashGel camera and from an iPhone (3GS) camera using our DIY box.

lines.text: The picture might seem a bit strange because we ran an old ladder, but its easy to see the huge difference between the two pictures.
lines.text_raw: The picture might seem a bit strange because we ran an old ladder, but its easy to see the huge difference between the two pictures.

guide.summary: Create a replacement for the Lonza FlashGel Camera using common materials found in a laboratory, for 1/50 the price. Save hundreds of dollars for a better lab-made DIY product.
guide.title: DIY Lonza FlashGel Camera Replacement
